name: Vitamin B1
description: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamin, is a water-soluble vitamin essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function. It is commonly included in energy supplements to support energy production in the body.

intakePractices.dosage: The RDA for adults is 1.1-1.2 mg per day. Supplements typically range from 50-100 mg per dose for therapeutic purposes.
intakePractices.timing: Can be taken any time of day, preferably with a meal to enhance absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: No specific restrictions noted, but high doses should be used under medical supervision to avoid potential side effects.

supplementInteractions.description: Magnesium can enhance the activation of thiamin into its active form, thiamin pyrophosphate.
supplementInteractions.recommendation: Consider taking thiamin with magnesium-containing supplements for optimal effect.

supplementInteractions.description: Chronic alcohol consumption can deplete thiamin levels, increasing deficiency risk.
supplementInteractions.recommendation: Avoid excessive alcohol when supplementing with thiamin, and consider higher doses under medical guidance if deficient.

foodInteractions.description: Diets high in refined carbohydrates can increase the body's need for thiamin.
foodInteractions.recommendation: Ensure adequate thiamin intake when consuming a high-carb diet.

foodInteractions.description: Raw fish contains thiaminases, enzymes that can degrade thiamin and reduce its availability.
foodInteractions.recommendation: Avoid consuming raw fish when relying on thiamin supplements.

name: Vitamin B2
description: Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin, is a water-soluble vitamin critical for energy metabolism, red blood cell formation, and maintaining healthy skin and eyes. It is often included in energy supplements to support cellular energy production.

intakePractices.dosage: The RDA for adults is 1.1-1.3 mg per day. Supplements typically range from 25-100 mg for therapeutic use.
intakePractices.timing: Best taken with a meal to improve absorption.
intakePractices.specialInstructions: High doses may cause yellowing of urine, which is harmless. Consult a healthcare provider for prolonged high-dose use.

supplementInteractions.description: Riboflavin may enhance iron absorption and utilization, supporting red blood cell production.
supplementInteractions.recommendation: Consider taking riboflavin with iron supplements if addressing anemia.

supplementInteractions.description: Tricyclic antidepressants may reduce riboflavin levels in the body.
supplementInteractions.recommendation: Monitor riboflavin status if on tricyclic antidepressants and supplement if necessary.

foodInteractions.description: Dairy products are rich in riboflavin and can complement supplementation.
foodInteractions.recommendation: Consider taking riboflavin supplements with dairy if tolerated.

foodInteractions.description: Chronic alcohol consumption can impair riboflavin absorption and increase deficiency risk.
foodInteractions.recommendation: Limit alcohol intake to optimize riboflavin supplementation.
